title: U.S. stock futures climb as investors shrug off hot inflation report, focus on lower yields; August PCE inflation came in hotter than Wall Street expected
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average YM00 rose 27 points, or 0.1%, to 29,312.

* Futures on the S&P 500 ES00 gained 8.3 points, or 0.2%, to 3,662.

* Futures on the Nasdaq 100 NQ00 increased 24 point, or 0.2%, to 11,252.

On Thursday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA fell 458 points, or 1.54%, to 29,226, the S&P 500 declined 79 points, or 2.11%, to 3,640, and the Nasdaq Composite COMP dropped 314 points, or 2.84%, to 10,738.

So far, the S&P 500 has slumped 3.8% in the third quarter and lost 24% over the last three quarters.

What's driving markets

After wavering between gains and losses in early trading, U.S. stocks looked set to open higher as Treasury yields fell.

"If you look at the yield curve, we're finally seeing some pullback both in the 2s and the 10s," said Art Hogan, chief market strategist at B.Reily Wealth.

The yield on the 2-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD02Ywas marginally higher at 4.176%, while the 10-year yieldBX:TMUBMUSD10Y fell 4 basis points to 3.708%.

However, investors were also forced to contend with a reading from the personal-consumption price index — the Federal Reserve's preferred gauge of inflation — which showed that prices rose in August after falling in July.

The so-called core PCE jumped 0.6% last month, which was above Wall Street's 0.5% forecast.

Hogan cautioned that stocks could be in for a volatile session since Friday marked the last trading day of the month of September, as well as the third quarter.

See: Cheaper gas holds down inflation, PCE shows, but the cost of everything else is still going up fast

Another wave of Fed speakers hits the tape on Friday, with Vice Chair Lael Brainard making her first comments of the week at 9 a.m. Eastern.

Outside the U.S., the beleaguered British pound GBPUSD rose above pre mini-budget crisis levelsearlier in the day, helped by Wednesday's decision to buy long-dated gilts, as well as a decision by the U.K. government to meet with the country's independent budget forecasters. However, the pound was once again on the backfoot, down 0.8% to $1.1035.

One day earlier, a downgrade of Apple AAPL by Bank of America, a report of a hiring freeze at Meta Platforms META and a steady stream of hawkish commentary weighed on U.S. stocks on Thursday, after a tumultuous week that included bond-buying intervention from the Bank of England.

Stocks in focus

* Shares of Nike Inc. NKE tumbled 9% in premarket trade after executives at the sportswear maker said price cuts to clear stockpiles from warehouses in North America would dent gross margins for the rest of the fiscal year. Analysts were raising red flags and cutting prices targets on the stock.

* Micron Technology MU stock rose after a report that Japan will grant it a $320 million subsidy to make advanced memory chips at its Hiroshima plant. That came a day after Micron posted quarterly earnings that included a forecast for a loss in the coming quarter and plans to scale back a build out of capacity.

— Barbara Kollmeyer contributed to this report
